//-1: Going off the Rule of Nines for body proportions and assuming about 20 ft sq
//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making this a 14-layer jack, sheets are 1x2 feet. 49 sheets for the vest and 18 sheets for the arms (67 total).
//1: human torso is about 7 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 14 (layers) x 3.5 (surface area) = 3920g
//2: human arms is about 3 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 12 (layers) x 1.5 (surface area) = 1440g
description: A thick cloth jack, intended to be worn below metal armor.  This one is made of over a dozen layers of tough canvas, and it provides fairly decent protection on its own.

//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making this a 14-layer jack, sheets are 1x2 feet. 49 sheets total.
//1: human torso is about 7 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 14 (layers) x 3.5 (surface area) = 3920g
description: A thick cloth vest, intended to be worn below metal armor.  This one is made of over a dozen layers of tough canvas, and it provides fairly decent protection on its own.

//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making these 12 layer pants, sheets are 1x2 feet. 36 sheets total
//1: human legs is about 6 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 12 (layers) x 3 (surface area) = 2880g
description: Tough cloth pants worn alongside an aketon underneath metal armor.  These are made of many layers of canvas offering solid protection.

//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making this 8 layers, sheets are 1x2 feet. 3 sheets total
//1: human neck is about 0.75 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 8 (layers) x 0.375 (surface area) = 240g
description: A cloth gorget made of many canvas layers.  A little warm but keeps your throat safe from danger, and it will fit under metal armor too.

//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making this 8 layers, sheets are 1x2 feet. 10 sheets total
//1: human head total is about 2.5 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 8 (layers) x 1.25 (surface area) = 800g
description: A cloth coif with neck and forehead protection.  Resting on your shoulders, it serves as padding for a helmet.  Though it's pretty warm, it is constructed of tough canvas and provides substantial protection even on its own.

//-1: Going off the Rule of Nines for body proportions and assuming about 20 ft sq
//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making this a 14-layer jack, sheets are 1x2 feet. 105 sheets for the vest and 36 sheets for the arms (67 total).
//1: human torso is about 7 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 30 (layers) x 3.5 (surface area) = 8400g
//2: human arms is about 3 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 24 (layers) x 1.5 (surface area) = 2880g

8 layers thick waist. human waist is about 3ft circumference with the extra padding, and reaches to about below knees. doesn't usually cover the whole circumference so guessing about 1.5x2.5x8 total surface area divided by 1x2 ft for about 15-18 extra sheets, about 1200g if 15 sheets.
description: A thick cloth greatcoat intended to be worn as standalone armor, as it's a little too thick to comfortably add chainmail or a cuirass on top.  Made of thirty layers of tough canvas, this will protect you from almost everything, but it's very heavy and warm.  The sleeves are a bit thinner for flexibility and it drapes below your legs, providing additional protection there.

description: A thick cloth surcoat intended to be worn as standalone armor, as it's a little too thick to comfortably add chainmail or a cuirass on top.  Made of thirty layers of tough canvas, this will protect you from almost everything, but it's very heavy and warm.  It drapes below your legs, providing additional protection there, and it lacks sleeves entirely.

//: roughly 0.25mm per sheet of canvas making these 24 layer pants, sheets are 1x2 feet. 72 sheets total
//1: human legs is about 6 sq. feet.  80g (canvas) x 24 (layers) x 3 (surface area) = 5760g

name.str_pl: pairs of canvas heavy arming pants

description: Tough, extremely thick cloth pants worn on their own alongside a gambeson.  These are made of a huge number of canvas layers offering very solid protection, though they're too thick to easily add metal armor on top and are both stuffy and restrictive.
